ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to write medically.

Definitely improved as a writer from the course, you touch on a lot of different type of medical writing (book reviews, op ed, news article etc). I was skeptical at first but I think every writing assignment truly improved my writing! Also the guest lectures were great. Randi obviously cares a lot about helping improve her student's writing.
I learned how to improve my writing skills and write better about medicine and public health topics
i learned a lot of writing skills and important things to consider while writing and organizing. i also learned a lot of material in general from the readings we did
My nonfiction writing skills greatly improved! I learned so much about how to approach science/medical writing, all the way from organization to word choice.
Medical writing, patient profile, digesting science into something more fun!

How to write News, Personality Profiles, Opinions, Book Reviews, etc. How to use adverbs effectively, write a good Nut Graf, develop suspense, use metaphors, etc. Other than writing, as a non pre-med student, I learned a lot about medicine and science, what is a "good" study, and the importance of investigation. We read the "Great Pretender" by Suzannah Cahalan and listened to Donor 9623, which were both so gripping and had great writing. We also had a lot of amazing guest lecturers who gave incite on what it's like to be a writer.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: everything. Prof Epstein is a great professor. Amazing. Phenomenal. I feel like I actually learned something (which is pretty rare)

Weaknesses: It is hard work. And grades seem tough.
I personally really enjoyed the class. I think the workload is manageable if you just stay on top of your readings/essays. Try not to leave the final assignment interviews until the very end.
I wish we had more feedback and more opportunities to workshop in class. It would be great if everything could have three drafts instead of two to give us more opportunities to improve.

i liked how the professor was able to interact with, get to know, and provide feedback to everyone. the readings helped me think about my own writing, and the individualized feedback i got on each thing i submitted was very helpful. the workshops were also helpful to see how others approach the same thing

Strengths: Prof. Epstein is fantastic at leading/supporting discussions and giving feedback, our readings were interesting and complementary to what we learned, cool guest speakers to meet and learn from, assignments were engaging and just the right amount of challenging, course clearly built on itself in the best way. Weaknesses: None?? Just wish we could've been in person of course.

Strengths: Professor Epstein is an amazing professor and writer. We also wrote a whole lot in the class and got a taste of different writing styles before diving in to the final paper. 

Weaknesses: There was SO much work that sometimes I did not know how I was going to do everything. This was more work than my STEM courses.

This has been my favorite course at Yale thus far. We only had 8 people in the class (including the professor), so we were able to read a lot of each other's writings, and everyone participated in class discussions. Professor Epstein also gave us fun activities to do and shipped us cute prizes. The deadlines came fast, but Professor Epstein was always very accessible and kind. This class is a lot of work, either a first or second draft is due every week. The final paper was a lot longer than I had expected, 3 times the word count of anything we had written before. I thought we could've done a third draft for the final paper. All in all, though, Professor Epstein is a great teacher and made this COVID semester a lot less sucky.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Truthfully I think the class went well over zoom. The prizes were always a very nice addition too!
i thought the prof was especially accommodating during such hard times and made sure all her students were okay

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! you will learn so much. It's hard work, but it's worth it.
definitely! Randi is great, you learn a lot. I don't have a writing background and found the class very accessible but still challenging.

I would recommend this course to anyone looking to improve their writing and learn how to communicate scientific concepts effectively, but make sure that you don't have a high workload in other class.
yes, super helpful especially if you want to go into medical field or writing about it
Absolutely! Take this course to learn how to write science/medical nonfiction, you won't regret it.
yes
Yes!! Even if you're not Pre-Med, this is a worthwhile class.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: small class with a lot of discussion
